--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Selvakumar Ganesan"
<selvakumar.ganesan@w...> wrote:
> Hi,
> I am trying to estimate effort for writing a regression test suite 
> based on Junit for an existing system. 

Our approach/view is that you do not want to strive to build a fully
comprehensive test suite from the beginning.. for just the reason you
discovered.. it's a BIG time investment.  What you want to do is
maximize the ROI of the time spent writing tests (i.e. get the biggest
bang for the buck).  You need to find places in the codebase that
would benefit the most from adding tests and go after those first. 
You just keep plugging away at it.. What's the worst problem?  Deal
with it.  Now what's the worst problem.  Deal with it.. etc.  Also,
when you work on a piece of code, wrap it in some tests first.  As you
have more & more tests in place, you'll be better able to refactor
into something that is more testable.. so you can add more & better
tests.  Getting a legacy codebase under test (and under control!)
isn't a big bang effort... it's gradual... part of everyone's daily work.

I'm actually working on something very similar at the moment.. using
metrics (with TCC in fact) to find places in the codebase that need
attention.

Dave
